title: 106_s2776
content: The "Medical Research Investment Act of 2000" increases the limitation on charitable deduction for contributions for medical research. The "Medical Research Investment Act of 2000" raises the limit on charitable deductions for medical research contributions to 80 percent of the taxpayer's contribution base for any taxable year. The "Medical Research Investment Act of 2000" increases the limit on charitable deductions for medical research contributions to 80 percent of the taxpayer's contribution base for the taxable year. Excess contributions can be carried over for up to 10 succeeding taxable years as medical research contributions. Excess contributions can be carried over for up to 10 succeeding taxable years as medical research contributions, treated in accordance with subsection (d)(1). Capital gain property contributions are subject to subsection (e)(1). For medical research contributions, the term 'medical research contribution' refers to a charitable donation designated for conducting medical research to specific organizations. The term 'medical research' is defined as per regulations under subparagraph (A)(ii). The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include provisions for medical research contributions, specifying the eligibility and criteria for such donations. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include medical research contributions, expanding eligibility and criteria for donations. Amendments apply to contributions made after December 31, 2000, and before that date if a deduction would be allowed under section 170. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include medical research contributions, expanding eligibility and criteria for donations. The amendments apply to contributions made on or before December 31, 2000, to the extent that a deduction would be allowed under section 170 for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. SEC. 3. Treatment of certain incentive stock options. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended regarding the treatment of incentive stock options. A new exception is added for certain medical research stock transfers. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new exception for medical research stock transfers, defined as the transfer of stock traded on an established securities market or acquired through the exercise of an incentive stock option in the same taxable year. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new exception for medical research stock transfers, defined as the transfer of stock within the same taxable year, meeting specific requirements. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new exception for medical research stock transfers, defined as the transfer of stock meeting specific requirements. The amendments apply to transfers made after the date of the enactment of this Act.
